image.altText: Clive Palmer poses for a photograph in front of a statue of Jeff the dinosaur.

items.synopsis: More than 20 construction staff have gathered outside Clive Palmer's resort on the Sunshine Coast following an apparent workplace dispute.

title.children: Trade staff locked out of Clive Palmer's Coolum resort after allegedly receiving termination letters

image.altText: A night time photo of a Queensland Police Service car with its blue light illuminated.

items.synopsis: A 52-year-old man will face court today after an alleged home invasion left a teenage boy with a stab wound.

title.children: Boy stabbed during alleged 'harrowing' home invasion on the Gold Coast

image.altText: Dust rising off a mine site with green hills in the foreground and background

items.synopsis: The discovery of heavy metals in the blood and rainwater of those living near a gold mine in New South Wales has sent shock waves through the community and sparked a major investigation.

title.children: Major investigation into gold mine after heavy metals found in residents' blood and rainwater

image.altText: A young man wearing black wayfarer sunglasses holds a sign that reads vive la Russia, vive la Niger

items.synopsis: Across West Africa, a sweeping popular movement shaped by anger towards France, the country's former coloniser, is gathering steam and Vladimir Putin is watching very closely.

title.children: Anti-colonialism is rippling through Africa, but Putin's enemy could reap the benefit

image.altText: Black and yellow Taser 10 device

items.synopsis: The weapons can be used at a range of 13.7 metres — more than triple the distance of the tasers currently used by Queensland police officers.

title.children: Queensland Police Service to trial taser with longer reach amid scrutiny over fatal shootings

image.altText: Caitlin Foord cups her hand around her ear while smiling and looking towards the crowd

items.synopsis: France midfielder Kenza Dali says her team is ready for a hostile atmosphere in their Women's World Cup quarterfinal against Australia, and is on high alert for star Matilda Caitlin Foord.

title.children: 'The crowd is going to be against us': France braced for hostile Matildas atmosphere and in-form Caitlin Foord

image.altText: Man in hi-vis and hard hat helps a shirtless man down a ladder

items.synopsis: The military tactic known as a "double tap" lures rescuers to the scene of the first strike before launching a second attack to injure them.

title.children: Ukraine accuses Russia of 'double tap' strikes targeting rescuers

image.altText: Commonwealth Bank signage outside Brisbane branch

items.synopsis: The Commonwealth Bank posts a record profit of $10.2 billion, up 5 per cent on last financial year.

title.children: Commonwealth Bank earnings top $10b as interest rate rises boost profit margins

image.altText: Mark Bailey gesturing and speaking.

items.synopsis: Last week Mark Bailey insisted it was an "error" and a "stuff-up" that the outdated cost had been published in a media release.

title.children: Queensland minister's staff suggested 'deleting' reference to $9.5b cost of train project, bureaucrat says

image.altText: A house on a rural block.

items.synopsis: Police continue to investigate three suspected mushroom poisoning deaths after a family lunch last month in Leongatha in Victoria's east. Detectives have not laid any charges, but say the woman who served the meal remains a suspect. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: Three dead and another fighting for life: What we know so far about suspected mushroom poisonings in Victoria

image.altText: Indigenous Australian holding an Aboriginal flag

items.synopsis: What will — and won't — change now the WA government has confirmed it is repealing the controversial Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act. Jake Sturmer explains everything you need to know.

title.children: What will — and won't change — after the WA government sensationally backflipped on its cultural heritage laws

image.altText: Two men wearing black burn lgbt rainbow flag

items.synopsis: The word, alongside the term "gender", will be banned from all apps licensed under the Iraq media regulator.

title.children: Iraq bans the term 'homosexuality', asks media to use 'sexual deviance' instead

image.altText: Lawyers, who support Pakistan's former Prime Minister Imran Khan, hold a protest against Khan's imprisonment.

items.synopsis: Imprisoned former Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan is barred from politics for five years as he launches an appeal on his conviction on graft charges.

title.children: Jailed ex-PM Imran Khan barred from Pakistan politics for five years as he launches appeal

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank sign sits outside a branch of the bank, March, 2008.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is expected to fall in morning trade, following broad losses on Wall Street as ratings agency Moody's downgraded several US banks. Reporting season continues with results from Commonwealth Bank and Suncorp. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: CBA, Suncorp profits jump, ASX to slip as Moody's downgrades US banks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wall Street's banking stocks fell sharply overnight, dragging the S & P 500 index 0.4% lower. This was after Moody's cut the credit ratings of several small to mid-sized US banks on Monday and said it might downgrade some of America's biggest lenders, warning that the sector's credit strength would likely be tested by funding risks and weaker profitability. Moody's slashed the ratings of 10 banks by one notch and placed six banking giants, including Bank of New York Mellon, US Bancorp, State Street and Truist Financial on review for potential downgrades. "Many banks' second-quarter results showed growing profitability pressures that will reduce their ability to generate internal capital," Moody's said in a note. "This comes as a mild US recession is on the horizon for early 2024 and asset quality looks set to decline, with particular risks in some banks’ commercial real estate (CRE) portfolios." Moody's said elevated CRE exposures are a key risk due to high interest rates, declines in office demand as a result of remote work, and a reduction in the availability of CRE credit. The agency also changed its outlook to negative for eleven major lenders, including Capital One, Citizens Financial and Fifth Third Bancorp. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank earlier this year sparked a crisis of confidence in the US banking sector, leading to a run on deposits at a host of regional banks despite authorities launching emergency measures to shore up confidence. Still, Moody's cautioned that banks with sizable unrealized losses that are not reflected in their regulatory capital ratios are vulnerable to a loss of confidence in the current high-rate environment. The sweeping report comes against the backdrop of tightening monetary conditions after the fastest pace of interest rate increases by the US Federal Reserve in decades slows demand and borrowing. The higher rates have also raised the spectre of recession and put pressure on sectors such as real estate to adjust to post-pandemic realities. - Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Moody's downgrades US banks, warns of possible cuts to others

children.content: Wall Street's banking stocks fell sharply overnight, dragging the S
P 500 index 0.4% lower.

This was after Moody's cut the credit ratings of several small to mid-sized US banks on Monday and said it might downgrade some of America's biggest lenders, warning that the sector's credit strength would likely be tested by funding risks and weaker profitability.

Moody's slashed the ratings of 10 banks by one notch and placed six banking giants, including Bank of New York Mellon, US Bancorp, State Street and Truist Financial on review for potential downgrades.
"Many banks' second-quarter results showed growing profitability pressures that will reduce their ability to generate internal capital," Moody's said in a note.
"This comes as a mild US recession is on the horizon for early 2024 and asset quality looks set to decline, with particular risks in some banks’ commercial real estate (CRE) portfolios."
Moody's said elevated CRE exposures are a key risk due to high interest rates, declines in office demand as a result of remote work, and a reduction in the availability of CRE credit.
The agency also changed its outlook to negative for eleven major lenders, including Capital One, Citizens Financial and Fifth Third Bancorp.

The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank earlier this year sparked a crisis of confidence in the US banking sector, leading to a run on deposits at a host of regional banks despite authorities launching emergency measures to shore up confidence.

Still, Moody's cautioned that banks with sizable unrealized losses that are not reflected in their regulatory capital ratios are vulnerable to a loss of confidence in the current high-rate environment.
The sweeping report comes against the backdrop of tightening monetary conditions after the fastest pace of interest rate increases by the US Federal Reserve in decades slows demand and borrowing.
The higher rates have also raised the spectre of recession and put pressure on sectors such as real estate to adjust to post-pandemic realities.
- Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Italy dealt a surprise blow to its banks and sent shockwaves across the sector in Europe by setting a one-off 40% tax on profits reaped from higher interest rates, after reprimanding lenders for failing to reward deposits. Sharply higher official interest rates have yielded record profits for banks, as the cost of loans soared while lenders held off paying more on deposits. Countries such as Spain and Hungary have already imposed windfall taxes on the sector and others may now follow suit. Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's government had floated the idea earlier in the year, but appeared to have cooled on the plan. Since then, however, bumper first-half results from banks brought the issue back into focus and prompted the government to act on the eve of the summer political shutdown. Lenders in Italy have passed on to depositors on average 12% of the rise in rates, versus 22% in the euro area, financial firm Jefferies calculated. "One has only to look at banks' first-half profits ... to realise that we are not talking about a few millions, but ... of billions," Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini told a news conference in Rome late on Monday. "If (it is true that) the burden deriving from the cost of money has ... doubled for households and businesses, what current account holders receive has certainly not doubled." Italy's banking share index had plunged 7.3% on Tuesday (local time), with sector leader Intesa Sanpaolo down 8.6% and rival UniCredit down 5.8%. Italian banks are up 50% over the past year, outperforming a 20% European sector rise. The Italian government wants to use the proceeds to help those struggling with the cost of living, such as mortgage holders. - Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Italy shocks banks with 40% windfall tax for 2023

children.content: Italy dealt a surprise blow to its banks and sent shockwaves across the sector in Europe by setting a one-off 40% tax on profits reaped from higher interest rates, after reprimanding lenders for failing to reward deposits.
Sharply higher official interest rates have yielded record profits for banks, as the cost of loans soared while lenders held off paying more on deposits.
Countries such as Spain and Hungary have already imposed windfall taxes on the sector and others may now follow suit.
Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's government had floated the idea earlier in the year, but appeared to have cooled on the plan.
Since then, however, bumper first-half results from banks brought the issue back into focus and prompted the government to act on the eve of the summer political shutdown.
Lenders in Italy have passed on to depositors on average 12% of the rise in rates, versus 22% in the euro area, financial firm Jefferies calculated.

"One has only to look at banks' first-half profits ... to realise that we are not talking about a few millions, but ... of billions," Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini told a news conference in Rome late on Monday.
"If (it is true that) the burden deriving from the cost of money has ... doubled for households and businesses, what current account holders receive has certainly not doubled."
Italy's banking share index had plunged 7.3% on Tuesday (local time), with sector leader Intesa Sanpaolo down 8.6% and rival UniCredit down 5.8%.
Italian banks are up 50% over the past year, outperforming a 20% European sector rise.
The Italian government wants to use the proceeds to help those struggling with the cost of living, such as mortgage holders.
- Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Finance Sector Union (FSU) has reacted to Commonwealth Bank's $10.2 billion annual profit, arguing the bank is making a "huge profit" at the expense of workers. “Very obviously, the CBA can afford to pay more," FSU national secretary Julia Angrisano said. "Their proposed pay rise would be a pay cut in real terms, given inflation. "The finance industry would expect the CBA to provide industry-leading wage increases given their industry-leading profits.” The FSU recently lodged a dispute at the Fair Work Commission to contest the bank's requirement for staff to return to the office 50% of the time. “CBA’s record profit demonstrates that staff can continue to work productively while maintaining their current work-from-home arrangements. "The return to office mandate is clearly not necessary and we are therefore disappointed that CBA has chosen not to address these significant concerns during the Fair Work proceedings”.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA making 'huge profit' at workers' expense, union says

children.content: The Finance Sector Union (FSU) has reacted to Commonwealth Bank's $10.2 billion annual profit, arguing the bank
is making a "huge profit" at the expense of workers.
“Very obviously, the CBA can afford to pay more," FSU national secretary
Julia Angrisano
said.
"Their proposed pay rise would be a pay cut in real terms, given inflation.
"The finance industry would expect the CBA to provide industry-leading wage increases given their industry-leading profits.”
The FSU recently lodged a dispute at the Fair Work Commission to contest the bank's requirement for staff to return to the office 50% of the time.
“CBA’s record profit demonstrates that staff can continue to work productively while maintaining their current work-from-home arrangements.
"The return to office mandate is clearly not necessary and we are therefore disappointed that CBA has chosen not to address these significant concerns during the Fair Work proceedings”.

image.altText: Three Afghan Australian men point to a sign reading 'Australian Capital Territory'. Two wear Afghan and Australian flags.

items.synopsis: Almost two years after the fall of Kabul, some Afghans in Australia are struggling to help their family members, who are endangered due to their support for Australia. Three men have embarked on a gruelling walk to Canberra to make their concerns heard.

title.children: These Afghan men walked 700km in the heart of winter to deliver a heartfelt message to Canberra

image.altText: The top five finalists in the 71st Miss Universe pageant in New Orleans.

items.synopsis: Six contestants file complaints with police, accusing organisers of sexual harassment in what was meant to be a costume fitting.

title.children: Miss Universe Indonesia contestants file complaint over inappropriate 'body checks'

image.altText: A woman in a purple top with white spots leaning on a tree and looking into the distance

items.synopsis: Sandra Deveson has waited more than four years for a mandatory inquest into the murder of her son, and has never been told when it might occur.

title.children: A 'broken system' has left Sandra still looking for answers four years after her son was murdered in jail

image.altText: A redacted, scanned photo of a drawing of a boat and a hangman game.

items.synopsis: Winnunga Nimmityjah Aboriginal health service says the ACT government transferred TJ Dennis into the NSW prison system from Canberra's jail, despite being urged not to for the sake of the inmate's mental health.

title.children: Indigenous man previously depicted in prison staff's hangman game dies in custody

image.altText: Four men sit on a carpet with Arabic script behind them.

items.synopsis: Britain First party leader Paul Golding takes to social media to criticise Brisbane for its "multiculturalism" in response to videos of the community's Ashura Procession.

title.children: British far-right leader prompts wave of racial abuse against Brisbane Muslims

image.altText: A black, grey, white and yellow illustration of woman with long black hair standing at front of a ship, with two men behind her.

items.synopsis: Behind the romantic, animated version of Pocahontas's life is a brutal reality. These people are determined to share it.

title.children: 'People need to know the truth.' The real story of Pocahontas is shockingly different from the movie

image.altText: two female students carrying handbags walk through a university campus. they are facing away from the camera

items.synopsis: Reports of sexual violence appear to be going up at Australian universities, but with public reporting of data inconsistent across the sector, there are fears the full extent of the problem remains underestimated.

title.children: Calls to update university student safety survey after fears true extent of assaults remains unknown

image.altText: A picture of the green Birkett Street sign at dusk

items.synopsis: A 37-year-old man is charged by homicide detectives with the murder of 35-year-old Tiffany Woodley. WARNING: Indigenous readers are advised this story contains photos of someone who has died.

title.children: Man charged with 'extreme' family violence murder of mother found dead in Perth home

image.altText: The

items.synopsis: The deepest parts of the Antarctic are difficult to explore but seals have helped reveal the mysteries below, and it's a thousand metres deeper than researchers thought.

title.children: Deep-diving seals find previously unknown underwater canyon

image.altText: Kids play on jumping pillow

items.synopsis: The iconic jumping pillow is facing an existential threat, with a growing number of caravan park and club operators being refused cover by insurers. Industry leaders warn the trend could have far-reaching consequences.

title.children: Jumping pillows are being removed due to insurance issues. Some say it's the 'tip of the iceberg'

image.altText: An artist's impression of an upgrade to a regional zoo.

items.synopsis: Regional projects across Queensland are being delayed, shelved or abandoned as huge cost blowouts hit cash-strapped councils.

title.children: Zoo upgrade ditched for new toilet block as cost blowouts leave councils reeling

image.altText: A man and a woman holding a photo of a child.

items.synopsis: A mother with 20 years' experience as a paramedic, who was unable to save her choking daughter, says suction devices should be mandatory in all schools and first aid kits.

title.children: Family calls for anti-choking devices in schools after two children die, but others say 'more studies needed'

image.altText: Margot Robbie in a scene from Barbie, and Cillian Murphy in a scene from Oppenheimer.

items.synopsis: Movie tickets are nearly always the same price, whether the film is a flop or a sold-out blockbuster. Why? And how much more does a trip to the movies cost than 20 years ago? Peter Martin explains.

title.children: If Oppenheimer is an hour longer than Barbie, why are tickets to see them the same price?

image.altText: An older man staring seriously at the camera

items.synopsis: A Melbourne couple had $370,000 stolen from bank accounts in a "horrific" case of identity theft. It has prompted calls for banks to sharpen up against scammers and fraudsters.

title.children: John had embarked on a family trip of a lifetime. By the time he got home, criminals had stolen his identity

image.altText: Australia's Hayley Raso tussles with France's Sakina Karchaoui during a football game.

items.synopsis: The Matildas need to take down France if they are to make the semifinals for the first time after Les Bleues' latest big win. Here are five things from the final round-of-16 games at the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Five quick hits — Matildas learn their quarterfinal opponent, and they're running hot

image.altText: A close up of a crocodile on a mud flat.

items.synopsis: Despite their reputation for being stealthy, crocodiles are very vocal. Now a group of Australian researchers are using video and audio monitoring to try to decipher what their calls mean.

title.children: Scientists are decoding saltwater crocodile 'talk'. And the reptiles have a lot to say

image.altText: A crowd gathering around a hearse with a picture of Sinead O'Connor on display.

items.synopsis: Thousands line the streets of Sinead O'Connor's hometown of Bray, Ireland to pay tribute to the singer before a private funeral.

title.children: 'Outpouring of love' as thousands farewell Sinead O'Connor in Ireland

image.altText: Megan Rapinoe on a soccer field, spreading her arms wide in celebration

items.synopsis: The veteran forward's impact on sport has been profound, and her legacy will last long after she is gone.

title.children: Despite the USA's World Cup exit, Megan Rapinoe has already won

image.altText: Scouts leave South Korea jamboree

items.synopsis: Teenagers from more than 100 countries, including over 900 Australians, have been evacuated from the World Scout Jamboree in South Korea in a logistical exercise of military-like precision.

title.children: One bus every 30 seconds: More than 37,000 teens evacuated from scout camp

image.altText: A group of young women in the same dresses and sashes smiling

items.synopsis: With not a sequin in sight, finalists at the Brisbane Ekka will be dressed in a uniform again this year, to help put them on an even footing amid the cost-of-living crisis.

title.children: How a navy dress is helping Queensland Showgirls fight the 'beauty pageant' mentality
